translated: Jātaka🔽Thirty-Third Chapter🔽The Chapter about Desires
The Gandhatinduka Birth-Story
“The state of heedfulness is the state of deathlessness,
The state of heedlessness is the state of death;
Those who are heedful do not die,
Those who are heedless are as if dead.

analyzed: madā pamādaḥ jāyetha  pamādā jāyate khayo
translated: From heedlessness arises intoxication,🔽From heedlessness arises destruction;
From destruction arises enmity,
Do not be heedless, O bull of the Bharatas.
For many kings have been conquered,
The kingdom has been destroyed by heedlessness;

analyzed: atha upi gāminaḥ gāmā  anagārāḥ agārinaḥ
translated: Then villages and towns have been destroyed,🔽The homeless have become householders.
For a heedless noble,
In the kingdom, the kingdom’s prosperity;
All the riches are destroyed,
This is said to be the king’s misfortune.
This is not the way, Great King,
You are heedless too much;
The prosperous and flourishing country,
The thieves are destroying it.
You will not have sons,
Nor gold, nor grain;
In the kingdom that is being destroyed,
You will be defeated by all your riches.
All the riches are exhausted,
For the king or the noble;
Relatives, friends, and loved ones,

The glory abandons the fool,

analyzed: jiṇṇavaḥ uragaḥ  su sa vihita kammanta
translated: like a snake its cast-off skin.🔽The glory increases for him

just as the cattle and the bulls increase🔽for the one who is skillful in action, who is not lazy, and who is diligent.
“Listen, great king,
wander in the country and the kingdom;
there, having seen and heard,
then you should act on it.”
“Thus may Pañcāla know,
having been struck in battle by a spear,
just as I now know,
having been struck by a thorn.”
“You are old and your eyes are weak,
you do not see well;
what is there for Brahmadatta,
that the thorn should go to him?”
“There is much for Brahmadatta,
I am on the road, brahmin;
the countryside is unprotected,
destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.
At night the thieves eat,
They eat by day with their beaks,
In the kingdom of King Kūṭa,
there are many unrighteous people.

analyzed: etādise bhaye jāte  bhayaṭṭā tāta māṇavā
translated: When such a danger has arisen,🔽the young men are frightened,
they make their wives shave their heads,
and take them into the forest”.

analyzed: kadāssu na amayam rājā  brahmadattaḥ marissati
translated: “When will this King Brahmadatta die,
whose kingdom is being conquered,
and young girls are not protected?”
“You have spoken badly, my son,
you who know the meaning of words.
Where is the king looking for a husband
for the young girls?”
“I have not spoken badly, brahmin,
I know the meaning of words.
The people are unprotected,
destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.
The thieves eat at night,
the crows eat by day;
In the kingdom of King Kūṭa,
there are many unrighteous people;
The wives are difficult to support and maintain,
where is the husband for the young girls?”
“Thus may Pañcāla lie,
slain in battle by a spear,
as this poor man lies here,
slain by a rice-pounder.”🔽“You are angry with King Brahmadatta,
my son, because of unrighteousness;
You are the one who is to blame,
not having restrained yourself.”🔽“Brahmin, I am angry with Brahmadatta
because he rules by the Dhamma.
The countryside is unguarded,
destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.
At night the thieves eat,
and by day the tax collectors.
In the king’s crooked kingdom
there are many unrighteous people.

original: Sā nūna puna re pakkā,🔽vikāle bhattamāhari;
analyzed: sā nūna punar re pakkā  vikāle
translated: Surely, the rice-cooker,🔽bringing food at the wrong time,
was killed by the rice-pounder
while waiting for the rice-cooker.”
“May Pancala be killed
in battle, struck down by the sword,
just as I have been struck down
and my milk has dried up.”🔽“When a cow sheds milk

analyzed: yam pasu khīram chaḍḍeti  pasu pālam vihisati
translated: and harms the cowherd,
what is Brahmadatta’s fault
that you blame him?”
“Brahmin, Pancala is to be blamed,
the king Brahmadatta,🔽because he rules by the Dhamma.
The countryside is unguarded,
destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.
At night the thieves eat,
and by day the tax collectors.
In the king’s crooked kingdom
there are many unrighteous people.
The fierce and wild cows,
which we did not milk before,
we milk today,
distressed for the sake of milk.”
“Let Pañcāla cry out like this,
with his son dead, with his hair dishevelled,
just like this poor cow,
with her calf dead, runs around.”
“If a beast of the king’s herd
should get lost or die,
who is to blame
for King Brahmadatta?”
“There is blame, Great Brahmā,
for King Brahmadatta.
The countryside is unprotected,
destroyed by the power of unrighteousness.
At night the thieves eat,
and by day the tax collectors eat;
in the kingdom of the crooked king,
there are many unrighteous people.
How is it that we are not protected,
and the people are destroyed, drinking milk?”
“Let Pañcāla cry out like this,
killed in battle with his son;
just like I am being eaten today,
by the villagers, born in the wilderness.”

translated: “Kings in the human world do not protect all beings,

analyzed: na id tāvatā rājā adhamma cārī
translated: up to this point a king is unrighteous,
Such a one as you, O Brahman, should not be given up to the crows.”
“A man of unrighteous appearance, indeed, is this religious man,
Who speaks unpleasantly to the Khattiya;
To the people who are scattered about,
He worships the king, the most heedless of all.

analyzed: sace idam brahme su rajjakam siyā
translated: If this, O Brahman, were to be a good thing,
The prosperous country would be joyful and clear;

analyzed: bhutvā balim agga piṇḍam ca kākā
translated: Having eaten the offering and the first portion of boiled rice,
Such a one as me, O Brahman, should not be given up to the crows.”
The Gandhatinduka Jātaka is the tenth.
The Thirty-Third Collection is finished.
The summary:
Kiṁchanda, Kumbha, Jayaddisa, Chaddanta,
Then Paṇḍitasambhava, Sirikapi,
Dakarakkhasa, Paṇḍaranāgavara,

original: Atha sambula tindukadevasutoti.🔽Jātakapāḷiyā paṭhamo bhāgo niṭṭhito.
translated: Then Sambula, Tinduka, and Devasuta.
